case_vignette: A 6 old female presents to clinic with a 2 month history of worsening itchy rash on the arms and legs that the patient constantly scratches at throughout the day. Father reports a history of eczema and asthma. Parents deny any recent new exposures to topical products, changes in detergent. They have tried over the counter hydrocortisone without improvement. Examination reveals poorly demarcated lichenified plaques along the antecubital fossas and popliteal fossas bilaterally with overlying excoriations.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've had an itchy rash on my arms and legs for 2 months that I keep scratching at all the time.
Have you noticed any blisters or pus-filled bumps in the rash?
No, I haven't noticed any blisters or pus-filled bumps.

What is your age and sex?

[Answer: Age and sex of the patient]

Do you have a history of allergies or asthma?

[Answer: Yes or No]

Do you take any medications regularly?

[Answer: Yes or No, if yes, specify the medications]

Does anyone in your family have a similar rash or skin condition?

[Answer: Yes or No, if yes, specify the relation and condition]

Final Diagnosis: Atopic Dermatitis (Eczema) if no family history, or Atopic Dermatitis with a positive family history.
